name: Isengard
description: A once-beautiful fortress in Rohan, transformed into a war machine by Saruman as a base for his conquest plans.

content.title: Overview
content.body: Isengard is a powerful fortress located in the valley at the southern end of the Misty Mountains, near Rohan's western borders. Historically a stronghold of Gondor and later Rohan, it was renowned for its imposing tower, Orthanc, black and unyielding, rising from a circle of stone walls and green countryside. By the time of 'The Two Towers,' Isengard becomes a center of industrialized warcraft under the direction of the corrupted wizard Saruman.

content.title: Appearance
content.body: Originally surrounded by lush woods and fertile lands, Isengard's landscape is transformed dramatically by Saruman’s machinations. The green trees are felled and replaced by vast pits, forges, and workshops that belch smoke and fire into the sky. The once-pristine gardens become wastelands filled with mechanical contraptions, weapon manufacturing, and a breeding ground for orcs. The tower Orthanc itself remains a stark, black monolith of shining stone, seemingly untouched by the devastation beneath it.

content.title: History
content.body: Isengard holds ancient significance, including ruins and foundations from Gondor’s stewardship era. The tower Orthanc was constructed by the Númenóreans as a watchtower and refuge. By the end of the Third Age, Saruman takes over Isengard and exploits its location and resources to build an army of orcs and Uruk-hai, aiming to rival Sauron. His deforestation of the surrounding land and industrialization mark a dark turn, emblematic of his fall from wisdom and alliance with darkness.

content.title: Story Significance
content.body: In 'The Two Towers,' Isengard is the primary base of operations for Saruman's war plans against Rohan and the rest of Middle-earth. The fortress serves as the staging ground for the attack on Rohan and the creation of the Uruk-hai army. The destruction of Isengard by the Ents, led by Treebeard, marks a critical turning point: a rebellion of nature against industrial tyranny. This event underscores themes of environmental destruction and the consequences of unchecked power.

content.title: Strategic Importance
content.body: Isengard's location makes it a strategic nexus between Rohan and the dark lands to the east. Control over this fortress allows Saruman to threaten the kingdom of Rohan and block the approaches to Gondor. Its defenses and fortifications are formidable, with Orthanc serving as a nearly impregnable center of power. The fortress's transformation from a place of refuge to a war machine mirrors Saruman's fall and the growing menace of war across Middle-earth.
